stem: An 80-year-old client is brought in by his daughter for a 6-month history of 'acting strange.' Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: 80-year-old male with a 6-month history of progressive decline in gait and cognition.
Background: The client has no prior history of stroke or significant medical conditions. He lives at home with his daughter, who reports the changes.
Assessment: At 14:00, the client exhibits a wide-based gait, described as a 'magnet gait,' where he appears to have difficulty lifting his feet. Cognitively, he demonstrates mild memory loss and slowed thinking. The daughter also reports recent onset of urinary incontinence, occurring primarily at night.
Recommendation: The neurology team recommends a large-volume lumbar puncture (LP) to assess for Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH). Monitor gait, cognition, and continence before and after the LP.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 128/78, HR 72, RR 16, T 98.4°F. Client is alert and oriented to person and place.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: CBC, CMP, and UA are within normal limits.

tabs.title: Radiology
tabs.content: CT Brain: Ventricle enlargement out of proportion to atrophy. No acute intracranial findings.

tabs.title: Cognitive & Mobility Differential
tabs.content:

actionOptions.text: Assess the client's gait and continence before and after a large-volume Lumbar Puncture (LP)

parameterOptions.text: Level of orientation and short-term memory

rationale.correct: The client presents with the classic triad of Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH): gait disturbance (wide-based, 'magnet gait'), cognitive impairment (mild memory loss, slowed thinking), and urinary incontinence. A large-volume lumbar puncture (LP) is often performed to assess if CSF drainage improves symptoms, which would indicate that a shunt may be beneficial. Assessing gait and continence before and after the LP (a1) helps determine the effectiveness of CSF drainage. Fall precautions (a2) are crucial due to the gait instability. Monitoring gait stability and urinary continence (p1) and cognitive function (p2) are essential to evaluate treatment effectiveness. The CT scan showing ventricle enlargement out of proportion to atrophy is also a key finding in NPH.
clinicalPearls: NPH is a potentially reversible cause of dementia.
The classic triad of NPH is 'Wet, Wacky, and Wobbly'.
A large-volume LP can help determine if a shunt is likely to be effective.
The gait disturbance in NPH is often described as a 'magnetic gait' or 'glue feet' gait.

questionTrap.trap: Assuming cognitive decline in an elderly patient is always Alzheimer's disease.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Consider other potential causes of cognitive decline, especially when accompanied by gait disturbance and urinary incontinence. The 'Wet, Wacky, and Wobbly' triad is highly suggestive of NPH. Also, review imaging for ventriculomegaly.

mnemonic.title: NPH Triad
mnemonic.expansion: Wet (urinary incontinence), Wacky (cognitive impairment), Wobbly (gait disturbance).
